page.title: 04WILD LIFE OF INNERLEITHEN
page.content: Shy{roe deer}emerge from the edge of the forest on Pirn Craig.There are hundreds of them in the forest.The reddish brown male has small branched antlers.They bark when surprised.There are also{Japanese Sika deer.Red {squirrels}swing in the oak trees.Grey intruders now balance our native red. If a{fox}has crossed your path it leaves a nasty smell.Trees mostly {Sitka Spruce}are felled for manufacturing chipboard furniture or fencing.Some exported to Scandinavia. Hovering above the Scree slopes is a {kestrel.}The tuneful song of the{Green {Woodpecker}was heard this term. {Moorhens}with white markings and {Mallards}with glossy green plumage nest by the Tweed.A{curlew}nests on the Golf Course by the Leithen.There is a heronry nearby.The tall{grey {heron}fishes in the Tweed.
